Notes: No new policy. Schools are teaching in-person with certain precautions. Ex. teachers wearing masks, students wearing masks.  On 13 January 2022, National Cabinet agreed to a national framework to promote a nationally consistent approach to the ongoing delivery of high-quality education for all students during COVID-19. This framework ensure all schools are open and be able to stay open, with as little disruption from COVID-19 as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322080316/https://www.dese.gov.au/covid-19/schools  https://archive.ph/mwzii

As of 31 March the majority of the Level 2 health measure in place were rolled back to Level 1 (Western Australia region). More widely, proof of vaccination requirements remain in place for certain businesses and venues (ex. hospitality) nationally.     Western Australia Level 1 measures are that:  Density and capacity limits  The 2 square metre (2sqm) rule and 500 patron capacity limit applies to:  -Licensed hospitality venues  -Nightclubs    Convention centres and function centres  The 2sqm rule also applies to:  -Fitness venues  -Entertainment venues  -Galleries and museums  -Places of worship  -Hairdressers, beauty services, spas, saunas, tattoo and massage parlours  -Perth Crown Complex  -Community, recreation or youth centre facilities.    Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  - everywhere indoors, other than in the home  - when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  - at hospitals and residential aged care or residential disability care facilities.    https://archive.ph/kUJ4m

As of 31 March the majority of the Level 2 health measure in place were rolled back to Level 1 (Western Australia region). Home gatherings are limited to a total of 10 people indoors and outdoors, except weddings and funerals. Vaccination status does not affect this limit.    Most other areas have either no limits or the nearest restriction is on ~100 people (Tasmania).    https://archive.ph/4RVp5  https://archive.ph/MPW9W

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are in effect which has eased travel but enforces restrictions against travel to Aboriginal communities. To help keep remote Aboriginal communities safe from COVID-19, there are strict travel restrictions in place. Tourists and travellers are not allowed to enter. Vaccination status does not affect this restriction.     Under the WA Governmentâs Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  - providing essential services and supplies  - going to work or school there  - entering for family or cultural reasons  - delivering a community program or activity  - entering in an emergency.  These people cannot enter a community if they have COVID-19 or symptoms of COVID-19, or if they are waiting for a test result or have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.  - Travellers can drive through a remote Aboriginal community only if they do not stop or come into contact with any person in the community.  - Police have the power to enforce the travel restrictions, and fines of up to $50,000 can be issued.    Other AUS regional restrictions vary but are more lenient.     https://archive.ph/8tKNt

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     Fully vaccinated Australian citizens, permanent residents, and eligible visa holders can travel to and from Australia without needing to apply for a travel exemption. All other people who are not fully vaccinated require a travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to applicable state and territory quarantine requirements.     The Australian government requires all individuals traveling to or transiting through Australia, with limited exceptions, to provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test at time of check-in.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084811/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084731/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      Under current restrictions, some people cannot visit a residential aged care facility. This includes people who:    - have returned from overseas in the past 14 days  - have been in contact with someone confirmed to have COVID-19 in the past 14 days  - are unwell, including with a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory illness (such as a cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  - need isolation or quarantine (unless directed by and managed per the direction of the local public health unit).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are now in effect. Part of these restrictions include external visitor restrictions for residential aged and disability care facilities:  - 2 visitors permitted per resident patient per day  - Masks must be worn by staff and visitors indoors and outdoors  - Proof of vaccination applies for visitors    National policy still in place outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://archive.ph/kUJ4m  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

With the rise of Omicron in March, schools moved back to online learning with some exemptions granted for key exam years. According to the Scoop's reporting:    BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN â Schools will suspend in-person learning and switch to online classes from March 7 as a surge in COVID-19 cases has caused low attendance among students, the government said Friday.    Announcing revised health guidelines at a press briefing, Minister at the Prime Ministerâs Office YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin Liew Abdullah said child care centres, kindergartens, primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres, as well as religious schools will return to virtual lessons for two weeks until March 19.    The decision to shift to virtual learning was made after a âsignificant reductionâ of students attending face-to-face classes, and focusing on online lessons would improve teaching delivery, the minister said.    Joining the news conference, the education minister said his ministry and religious affairs ministry found that it was better to synchronise teaching methods because educators are currently using different modes of delivery for learning.    See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.ph/4h01l

Brunei has returned to in-person teaching for most levels (except primary schools), after schools were moved online after the surge in Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron wave.    As reported by the Scoop,    'Child care centres, kindergartens, secondary schools, religious schools, colleges and sixth form centres will resume classroom learning on either April 4 or 5, pending the sighting of the moon this Friday which will determine the first day of Ramadan.    However only primary schools with less than 50 pupils â such as those in rural areas â will be allowed to reopen, while the rest must wait until the government kicks off its COVID-19 vaccination programme for children aged 5-11.    Face-to-face learning has been suspended since March 7 after schools reported low attendance at the height of the Omicron surge.    Before retuning to classrooms, the minister urged parents to conduct ART testing on their children twice a week and to regularly report their results to the school.    âIf there are any students experiencing symptoms such as a cold or cough, we hope parents or guardians can send them to the clinic for treatment and not send them to school.â    He added that adolescents aged 12 to 17 who are not yet vaccinated will be allowed to return to schools next week, rescinding a previous policy which did not allow unvaccinated children to attend in-person classes.    This recent announcement brings to an end the third school closure since the pandemic started. The first suspension of classroom learning lasted from March 26, 2020 to June 2, 2020, while the second closure spanned August 9, 2021 to January 2, 2022.'    See the Scoop's report, entitled "Schools to resume face-to-face learning next week", archived at https://archive.ph/ElXxD

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)    Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)   Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

As part of Bruneiâs National COVID-19 Recovery Framework, Brunei moved to its âearly endemic phaseâ on 15 December until 15 April 2022. Business premises including restaurants, fitness facilities, markets and cinemas can open at 75% capacity or 300 people, whichever is the lower number. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

Brunei?went into lockdown on 7 August 2021. Although measures have since relaxed, there are still restrictions in place. There is a daily curfew between 12am and 4am which will be lifted on 1 April 2022. Masks are mandatory for everyone over 2 years old when in public places, but may be removed when you are drinking or eating, or if you are exercising. There are financial penalties for not adhering to mask guidelines. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 15 April.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    The night-time curfews are no longer in force.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the original Operasi Pulih, published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Peralihan, published on 10 Nov, archived at https://archive.vn/gwb8w  See the Scoop's report on the early endemic phase, published on 12 Dec, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP  See the Scoop's report titled "Movement restrictions shortened from 12am to 4am", published on 10 Jan, archived at https://archive.vn/ttj9L  See the US Embassy in Brunei's COVID-19 Information update, archived at https://archive.vn/IQ9OR  See the Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the [US Embassy in Brunei's website](https://archive.ph/dgjiE), archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

Royal Brunei Airlines has suspended most of its routes until June 30, 2022, with limited scheduled service continuing to Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, London, Manila, Melbourne, and Singapore only.   Essential outbound travel is allowed for citizens and permanent residents, by obtaining a PMO exit travel approval, who have received two doses of vaccination within 14 days to three months (and no longer than six months) prior to departure or for those who have received a booster dose.   Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.    https://archive.ph/w7nh2

As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 08 Apr, foreigners are now allowed. As cross-border travel via land and sea is still suspended, the only way to enter Brunei now is via air.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    -   Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?Â  No.      -   Starting April 1, 2022, Brunei citizens and residents who have completed three doses of the COVID-19 vaccination, or two doses of the vaccinations within a three month period prior to departure, will be allowed to make non-essential travel to 11 Travel Green List nations (Australia, Cambodia, China, Japan, Korea, Malaysia (air travel only), New Zealand, Singapore, United Kingdom, United Arab Emirates, and Saudi Arabia). An exit travel approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office (PMO) is no longer required, particularly for air travel to all countries â whether included in the Travel Green List or otherwise.      -   Cross border travel by land and sea is still suspended.Â       -   Visit the?website of the Prime Ministerâs Office?for outbound travel details.      -   From April 1, 2022, all COVID-19 recovered inbound travelers in the past 90 days are exempted from providing a negative RT-PCR test and mandatory self-isolation with proof of recovery. Antigen Rapid Test (ART) is the only requirement on arrival.      -   All inbound travelers from Green List nations are required to undergo both RT-PCR and ART upon arrival in the country, serve their mandatory self-isolation at respective home residence or hotel until a negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained, as well as additional Day 2 and Day 3 ART (Day of arrival as Day 1) and upload ART results onto ART Reporting module on BruHealth App.      -   All inbound travelers from Non-Green List nations are required to undergo ART upon arrival, serve their mandatory self-isolation for five (5) days at respective home residence or hotel and undergo RT-PCR test at any accredited clinics on Day 5 post-arrival (Day of arrival as Day 1). Quarantine will be allowed to end as soon as negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained.      -   Visit the?website of the Prime Ministerâs Office?for inbound travel details.      -   All inbound and outbound travelers for a period of less than 90 days must provide proof of travel health insurance covering COVID-19 (minimum coverage of BND $50,000) from their preferred insurance company before exiting or entering Brunei.      -   Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.  -   Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?Â  **Yes.**      -   Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.  -   Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?Â  **Yes.**      -   Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.  -   Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration. Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/WNIKw

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID. No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS. No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

Masks are mandatory for everyone over 2 years old when in public places, but may be removed when you are drinking or eating, or if you are exercising. There are financial penalties for not adhering to mask guidelines.    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." 3 April 2022: A total of 666 children received their first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine on Saturday, as Brunei kicked off its COVID-19 vaccination drive for children ages 5-11.    The Ministry of Health (MoH) said 50,000 first doses have been made available for young children at six vaccination centres across the country.    âThe vaccine is voluntary and it is not being used as a kind of passport for children to be allowed back to school. Itâs part of our effort, besides bertawakkal, to prevent children from developing serious symptoms from COVID-19,â said health minister YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Isham Hj Jaafar.

The government had previously announced, and maintained that all vaccines would be provided for free to those resident in Brunei, regardless of citizenship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101213123/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19%20Vaccine.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101235238/https://thescoop.co/2021/04/02/covid-19-brunei-to-begin-mass-vaccination-on-april-3/

On 2022-04-09, the Tianjin Municipal Government issued a circular to strictly control the departure of teachers and students from school. The city implements closed campus management, school teachers and students do not leave Tianjin unless necessary, and do not teach offline unless necessary. For staff, students and outsourced service personnel who do have to leave Tianjin due to family visits and homecoming, etc., they should strictly implement measures to prevent and control the epidemic away from Tianjin, and report to the school before leaving, and provide proof of negative 48-hour nucleic acid tests and health code green codes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143410/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/cxzc/202110/t20211020_5657683.html

On 2022-04-06, Shanghai Chongming District issued a notice to suspend offline services at the office lobby of the District Administrative Service Centre during the period of unified implementation of closure and control management (the unsealing time is subject to notification by the prevention and control department) in accordance with the requirements of the epidemic prevention and control work.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410130018/https://www.shcm.gov.cn/ztzl/009004/009004001/20220406/45bfac2a-8ff3-403b-be52-460ba4c1aea5.html

On 2022-04-09, the municipal government of Chengde, Hebei Province, issued a notice that people returning to Chengde should fill in the "Chengde landing code" truthfully, take the initiative to cooperate with the registration of information, check the health code and travel code and other epidemic prevention measures, and take two more nucleic acid tests on the third day and seven days respectively, and refrain from going out until the results are available, and strictly forbid to enter or leave the gathering place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410131016/http://www.hebei.gov.cn/hebei/15067610/15068061/15069930/index.html

On 2022-04-08, the Nanjing Municipal Government issued a circular prohibiting crew members of ships with a history of travel to medium and high risk areas from boarding and disembarking. Those who need to go ashore due to special circumstances such as medical treatment of injuries should be approved by the local health department or the epidemic prevention and control command.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410133455/https://www.jiangsu.gov.cn/art/2022/4/8/art_83410_9986569.html

On 2022-03-29, the Changsha Municipal Government issued a notice stating that home isolators are to live strictly alone and have no contact with family members unless necessary. If they do not live alone, they are required to live in a single room and use their own bathroom, while keeping their room door closed at all times. During home isolation, N95 masks are to be worn throughout (if you do not have a stock, please contact your community for home delivery).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410134029/https://wappass.baidu.com/static/captcha/tuxing.html?ak=572be823e2f50ea759a616c060d6b9f1&backurl=https%3A%2F%2Fmbd.baidu.com%2Fnewspage%2Fdata%2Flandingsuper%3Fthird%3Dbaijiahao%26baijiahao_id%3D1728622354548133414%26c_source%3Dduedge&timestamp=1649598028&signature=40097750b97925f40c7c074de9ec78a1

On 2022-03-14, the Jilin Provincial Government issued a circular to ban the movement of people from the province across provinces and regions from 14 March 2022 in order to reduce the spillover and spread of the epidemic brought about by cross-provincial and cross-regional movement. If you need to go out under special circumstances, please register at the local police station and return to be isolated and controlled according to the relevant regulations on epidemic prevention and control. For those who violate the above provisions, the relevant departments will be held responsible in accordance with the law and discipline.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410133021/http://news.sohu.com/a/529962180_121106854

2022-04-09, Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province, the municipal government issued a circular, foreign entry personnel, the assignment of red code, the first entry point isolation period of 14 days, the return and implementation of "7 days of centralized isolation + 7 days of home isolation" medical observation; the first entry point isolation period of 21 days, the return and implementation of 7 days of home isolation medical observation, the isolation period no abnormal decoding.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410131745/https://m.thepaper.cn/baijiahao_17432680

Ministry of Health 1 Apr 22:  We now leave it to you to assess your own level of risk and decide to continue to take measures such as masking and social distancing. If you are at higher risk of severe disease should you get infected with COVID-19, we strongly recommend that you continue to wear a mask in public, particularly in crowded indoor spaces. The lifting of masking and other mandates, and easing of travel restrictions, is NOT a sign that the risk of outbreak and resurgence of COVID-19 is over. Additionally, both, Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are administered as booster doses to individuals aged 18 years and above. No policy change    The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology has issued Circular No. 2/2022 on Discretion Towards the Implementation of the four-minister joint decree on schooling during the COVID-19 pandemic. The circular stipulates that those areas where PPKM level 2 are implemented may limit face-to-face schooling to 50% of the class capacity.    The government is mulling over stopping its policy of opening schools to 100% physical attendance. The news comes after a proposal from Jakartaâs Governor Anies Baswedan to the Central Government over its 100% school reopening policy for one month due to concerns over the Omicron variant of COVID-19. Jodi Mahardi, a spokesperson for the Coordinating Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Investment, confirmed that the government was considering the proposal.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology has issued Circular No. 2/2022 on Discretion Towards the Implementation of the four-minister joint decree on schooling during the COVID-19 pandemic. In Java and Bali, areas under level 4 protocols allow non-essential and essential industries to operate on-site at 25 and 50-percent capacity, respectively. Level 3 restrictions permit on-site workforce caps of up to 50 percent in most industries and 75 percent in export-oriented industries. Level 2 curbs allow all sectors to operate on-site at a maximum of 75-percent capacity. Under level 1 protocols, all sectors can run at full capacity.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

Minister of Home Affairs Tito Karnavian has issued Minister of Home Affairs Instruction (Inmendagri) No. 8/2022 on the prevention and handling of COVID-19 during the Mandalika MotoGP in Pertamina Mandalika International Street Circuit, West Nusa Tenggara 2022. The instruction stipulates a maximum of 100,000 on-site viewers, and a maximum capacity of 10 percent for the festival grounds. All on-site viewers, racers, attendants, crew and officials must also be already fully vaccinated and present a negative PCR test result that is valid for 2x24 hour or a negative Antigen test result that is valid for 1x24 hour    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

Long-distance travellers to and from Java and Bali are required to show proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 (RT-PCR or rapid antigen) test result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220317213636/https://southeastasiabackpacker.com/covid19-indonesia-travel-restrictions/     Individuals utilizing public transport must comply with large-scale social distancing policies that include the mandatory use of face masks and maintaining appropriate physical separation. Due to social distancing measures, seating/standing space on public transport may be limited and schedules may be reduced.    https://archive.ph/cZ5qg

All long-distance travelers to and from Java and Bali using all modes of transport are required to show the vaccination card report (first dose is acceptable) and a certificate of negative RT-PCR test or rapid antigen test.    Travelers using air transportation who fly between airports on the island of Java and Bali, including flights from or to Java and Bali are required to present vaccination record (first dose is acceptable) and negative RT-PCR test which was obtained within 48 hours and fill-up e-HAC (Electronic Health Alert Certificate) prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220327182340/https://kemlu.go.id/losangeles/en/news/11727/update-indonesia-travel-restrictions

As of March 9, officials have lifted the pre-departure testing rule for fully vaccinated domestic travelers on air, sea, and land routes. Unvaccinated travelers must provide a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours or a RAT test taken within 24 hours before departure. All air and sea travelers must also register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel. Officials advise passengers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

The COVID-19 Task Force has issued Circular No. 11/2022 and Circular No. 12/2022 that relaxes the health protocol for, respectively, domestic and international travel during the COVID-19 pandemic. Circular No. 11/2022 stipulates that domestic travelers who are completely vaccinated are no longer required to show a negative Antigen or PCR Test Result. Meanwhile, Circular No. 12/2022 stipulates that Indonesians and foreigners travelling from abroad who have been completely vaccinated will only be required to quarantine for 1x24 hours. These circulars take effect starting March 8, 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220326153025/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

The Ministry of Finance has issued Minister of Finance Regulation No. 3/PMK.03/2022 on Tax Incentive for Taxpayers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Regulation stipulates the extension of the prevailing tax incentive on income tax, import tax on certain importers, as well as final income tax for construction services. The import tax incentive is effective until June 30, 2022, while the income tax and the construction services final income tax incentives is effective until the June 2022 tax period.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

On March 7, priority measures for the following 18 metropolitan areas or prefectures continue until March 21 2022:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kagawa, Kumamoto, Hokkaido, Aomori, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Ishikawa, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo.  Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy. Schools continue to remain open with increased vigilence in all prefectures. Students will be attending in-person schooling on alternative days to reduce capacity on school grounds for: Nagoya city and Shinjuku ward. Schools also have the jurisdiction to close in the event of an outbreak.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    No other changes to school measures. All schools and extracurricular activities continue to be open with precautions in place. Schools may also have the power to temporarily close should there be an outbreak.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

On March 7, priority measures for the following 18 metropolitan areas or prefectures continue until March 21 2022:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kagawa, Kumamoto, Hokkaido, Aomori, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Ishikawa, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo.  Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy. The following measures apply to all prefectures under priority measures: Require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table and may serve groups greater than 4 if proof of vaccination is shown. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  For all those in priority measures, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063439/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021127.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    No further restrictions for workplaces, restaurants, or retail space are in place. However, telework to reduce contact and infection precautions including hand hygiene and better ventilation continue to be encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

On March 7, priority measures for the following 18 metropolitan areas or prefectures continue until March 21 2022:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kagawa, Kumamoto, Hokkaido, Aomori, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Ishikawa, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo.  Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy as events continue to be held with restrictions of capacity.  For all those in priority measures, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063439/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021127.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    Events continue to be permitted and infection precautions are encouraged. There remains a maximum of 5000 people with 100% venue capacity for events with no loud noises, and a maximum of 5000 people with 50% venue capacity for events with loud noises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy as events continue to be held with restrictions of capacity.  For all those in priority measures, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    Events continue to be permitted and infection precautions are encouraged. There remains a maximum of 5000 people with 100% venue capacity for events with no loud noises, and a maximum of 5000 people with 50% venue capacity for events with loud noises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

No change to previous policy. The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. Telework is also encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government is looking to expedite the entry for authorized foreigners into Japan (i.e. those with valid travel VISAs for business or education purposes). Japan is looking to permit 150,000 foreign students to enter the country by the end of May 2022.  On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html

On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.  However, travel remains restricted to Visa holders and travel for tourism purposes continue not to be permitted entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020344/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220316/k10013534891000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322021949/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccinations for children 5-11 continue to be administered.  Third doses continue for the elderly and employees of small to medium size businesses. The government reports that about 70% of the elderly population in Japan had received their third doses by the end of February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311033316/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220308/k10013519761000.html

In December 2021, the Japan government released guidance for elderly homes in the country to resume face-to-face visitation with consideration for vaccination status after the 2nd dose and a negative PCR test result within 72-hours.  On March 31 2022, there remain reports of elderly homes in Ishikawa and Miyazaki prefectures (until April 24 2022) that continue restrictions for face-to-face visitation even after priority measures were lifted, including only allowing visitors to visit for 15-minutes behind visitation booths.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220405044716/https://www.asahi.com/articles/ASQ3Y7T66Q3YTNAB003.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220405043649/https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/340671  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201213054/https://www.asahi.com/articles/ASPCB5F84PCBUCLV004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220405043558/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/000867566.pdf

Schools have partially reopened with protocols, like mandating teachers and students to wear facemasks. Schools meeting 70 percent of the Health Ministryâs assessment indicators will be enabled to resume in-person learning from January 10, 2022. Their eligibility will be re-reviewed twice per week for the revision of virus measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315174743/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/laos-officials-reduce-quarantine-period-for-most-international-arrivals-to-seven-days-as-of-feb-4-update-42  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315174906/https://en.vietnamplus.vn/laos-to-pilot-school-reopening-from-january-2022/219661.vnp

On Mar 23, the Lao Ministry of Education and Sports issued a notice closing face-to-face classes at primary schools across the country. This involves both private and state-run schools, preschools and Grade 1-4. Affected classes will switch to remote learning.   Students in all higher grades will continue with face-to-face learning but all education institutions must comply with the 10 measures and 40 recommendations laid down by the education ministry to prevent the spread of Covid.  The notice came into effect the same day and will continue to be in effect until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221614/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Education_ministry59.php    https://archive.ph/VNyCI

Entertainment venues such as karaoke bars, tourism sites, night markets, food gardens, pubs, cinemas, snooker halls, shopping malls, and internet cafes must close.  Indoor and outdoor sports centers such as fitness centers, gyms, sports fields, swimming pools, and other sports venues may reopen, provided they abide by the COVID-19 prevention measures.  Garment factories and other types of factories must close. However, if the factory can guarantee that there is no risk of COVID-19, consideration for continuing operations will be made.  Retailers and food vendors may also open for the sale and delivery of food and daily necessities, provided they abide by the COVID-19 prevention measures.  The following entities are allowed to operate with adherence to COVID-19 prevention measures:  Massage parlors, spas, beauty parlors  banks and other financial institutions  gas stations and convenience stores  hospitals and medical centers  hotels and resorts  medical emergency services  pharmacies  postal service  supermarkets, agricultural and fresh markets  telecommunication, electricity, and water supply providers  restaurants and coffee shops    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No events with over 50 participants including religious activities, traditional ceremonies and weddings are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus

No events with over 50 participants including religious activities, traditional ceremonies and weddings are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221614/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Education_ministry59.php

A curfew is in place in Vientiane Capital region and any province with community spread from 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Restrictions are in place for provinces with community transmission. Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Travel is prohibited in localized areas (red zones) where community transmission of COVID-19 is present.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a recommendation to ease restrictions on entry to Laos for Lao nationals and foreigners holding labor visas (LA-B2), spouse visas (SP-3), or other types of multiple entry visas.  Upon arrival in Laos, a 48-hour quarantine period following an RT-PCR test for foreign residents arriving in Laos will remain in place, after which seven-day home isolation is authorized.    https://archive.ph/WfHQX    https://archive.ph/DgQyo

The government has approved a budget of 1.5 billion kip to disburse cash allowances for the poorest and provide other subsidies for almost 6,000 low-income earners and informal sector workers who have lost income due to the pandemic and suffer extreme financial hardship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315182601/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government includes income tax exemption for both civil servants and employees of the private sector with income less than 5 million kips per month for three months; profit tax exemption for microenterprises with annual income between 50â400 million kip for three months; duty fee exemption for imports of goods to be used towards the outbreak; and deferral of road tax payments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315182601/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:    All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccination priority groups include healthcare workers, people aged 60 and above, people with underlying health conditions, pregnant women, and essential workers such as schoolteachers, as outlined in the National Deployment and Vaccination Plan. Adolescents aged 12 to 17 years are also being prioritized for vaccines.    A nationwide vaccination programme for children aged 6 and over against Covid-19, started Feb 21, 2022.    The Ministry of Health plans to offer fourth doses of Covid-19 vaccines to healthcare workers and people at risk of serious illness starting next month, hoping to shield vulnerable groups from infection with the Omicron variant.    Currently 5 types of vaccines are available in Laos - Sinopharm, Astra Zeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer and Sputnik.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214054412/https:/www.phnompenhpost.com/international/laos-health-ministry-targets-8725-covid-shots-end-2022    https://web.archive.org/web/20220202225727/https:/la.usembassy.gov/the-united-states-provides-1698840-doses-of-the-pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-to-lao-pdr/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325222358/https:/www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2022/02/22/laos-govt-to-expedite-covid-19-vaccination-programme    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221409/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Health_phet.php

Land rental: Exemption of land rental under MOP$100.00.  Property tax: Standard deduction of MOP$3,500.00 on property tax. If the taxpayer is two or more natural persons (individuals), its property tax can be similarly deducted the aforementioned amount if and only if one of them is permanent resident of Macao SAR. If the taxpayer is a legal person, individual commercial entrepreneur or non-resident of Macao SAR, it is not eligible for such deduction.     Salaries tax: 30% exemption on salaries tax and the exemption allowance for its assessment in 2022 is MOP$144,000.00. In case of the following situation: employer should withhold tax from causal worker whose daily salary is over MOP$640.00 or employee whose monthly salary is over MOP$16,000.00. Please refer to the Simulation Calculation disposal in website of FSB. In addition, exemption allowance for part-time and employee who are aged 65 or above or with permanent disability level of or above 60%, is adjusted to MOP$198,000.00.    https://archive.ph/4NMvV

With decreasing Covid-19 cases across Myanmar, public schools, private schools, and monastic education schools in all the townships except 46 in nine regions and states close to border areas were reopened starting on November 1.  No further policy could be found since the reopening.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135128/https://elevenmyanmar.com/news/yangon-schools-see-just-over-80000-of-over-500000-enrollees-on-reopening-day

You must wear a face mask in all public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135812/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus

The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M.  In Rangoon, the curfew was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some domestic flights have resumed.   Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has resumed but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are limited due to the ongoing civil unrest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

During COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in Burma, residents may only leave their residence to travel to/from work, to buy groceries, or for medical treatment.  A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.  Authorities set up checkpoints in Rangoon and elsewhere to verify travelers are on the road for permitted reasons.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? â YES   Some domestic flights have resumed.   Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has resumed but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are limited due to the ongoing civil unrest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Authorities have extended international travel restrictions, including a ban on entry for most international travelers and the suspension of on-arrival visas and e-visas, through March 31.  Burmese authorities will no longer allow international commercial passenger flights to land at any airport in Burma.  This suspension will last until further notice.  All landing permissions previously granted are suspended.  Exceptions apply to ârelief flights, all-cargo flights, medical evacuation flights and special flights specifically approved by the Department of Civil Aviation.â All foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens and all diplomats and U.N. officials, are required to present laboratory evidence of absence of COVID-19 infection issued no more than 72 hours prior to the date of travel before boarding any airline destined to Burma. U.S. citizens have reported being asked to submit to a COVID-19 health examination as part of their in-country Burmese visa renewal process.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325142002/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/myanmar-officials-extend-covid-19-international-entry-restrictions-through-march-31-update-51  https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Household support- In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec. Transferring MMK 400 billion to Myanmar Economic Bank to establish a COVID 19 Fund to provide soft loans to affected businesses (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at 1 percent interest for one year. The repayment term was extended by six months; (ii) provision of MMK 600 billion loans to farmers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Household support- In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec. Transferring MMK 400 billion to Myanmar Economic Bank to establish a COVID 19 Fund to provide soft loans to affected businesses (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at 1 percent interest for one year. The repayment term was extended by six months;   Provision of MMK 600 billion loans to farmers.  Waiver of specific goods tax, customs duty, and commercial tax on critical medical supplies and products related to the prevention, control, and treatment of COVID-19;   Reduction of the income tax rate by half for real estate purchase, construction, access and establishment of new business on income up to 3 billion kyat     https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Authorities have authorized COVID-19 vaccinations for use in Burma, including the CoronaVac, AstraZeneca, CoviShield, Pfizer BioNTech, Comirnaty, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson, Moderna, Sinopharm, Sputnik, and Covaxin vaccines. These vaccines are broadly given to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups, and Elderly groups, and other essentials.   Myanmar government established the COVID-19 Vaccination Fund to procure vaccines. A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old).    https://archive.ph/UA9We

A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old). All the vaccination activities are recorded and reported in the Vaccine Management Information System-VMIS. Therefore, the COVID-19 vaccination program in Myanmar is currently active for 24 groups and is in a neutral manner without any discrimination, leaving no one behind irrespective of their ethnicity, religion, gender, socio-economic status, or political affiliation.     https://archive.ph/UA9We

Myanmar government established the COVID-19 Vaccination Fund to procure vaccines. No change in policies      Close proximity businesses are only open to people with a My Vaccine Pass  If you have a My Vaccine Pass, you can visit a close-proximity business, such as a hairdresser.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321103028/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/shopping-and-services-at-red/close-proximity-businesses-at-red/

Events can go ahead with My Vaccine Pass.  Indoor events are limited to 200 people. There are no capacity limits outdoors.  Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404102339/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

Gatherings can go ahead.  If everyone has a My Vaccine Pass, indoor gatherings are limited to 200 people, and outdoor gatherings have no limit.  If My Vaccine Passes are not being used, indoor and outdoor gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Children and babies are included in the gathering limits â but not people working at a gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404103324/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red//

You do not need a My Vaccine Pass to use public transport or taxi and ride-share services.  There are no physical distancing requirements on public transport, or at bus stops or train stations.  You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404103847/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/
No requirement for home stay    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404104635/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.  You can travel for any reason.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404103847/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

no coding changes for the period of 08-12 March 2022.    Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111938/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapore-to-simplify-covid-19-rules-from-march-15-including-allowing-five-household-visitors-at-a-time  __________________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 07 March 2022:  no coding changes for the period of 27 Feb - 07 Mar 2022.    Easing and streamlining of current covid measures to be delayed further as cases remain high.    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: The streamlining of COVID-19 safe management measures will be postponed again as daily local case numbers have remained high.  "The number of cases currently hospitalised also remains high, and our healthcare workers are still under significant pressure," said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Friday (Mar 4)."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220307093838/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-streamlining-safe-management-measures-delay-moh-high-case-numbers-2539831  _______________________  *** Please refer to notes dated 26 Feb 2022:  no coding changes for the period of 23-26 Feb 2022.  ____________________  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:  no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

No coding changes for the period of 13-28 March 2022    Streamlining of Covid measures delayed until 29 March 2022.    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - There will be an easing off on mandatory mask-wearing outdoors from next Tuesday (March 29), as Singapore moves towards a new phase of living with Covid-19.  This was among a number of key changes to measures implemented in the fight against the pandemic that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and the multi-ministry task force tackling Covid-19 announced on Thursday.  They include larger group sizes and the lifting of most restrictions for fully-vaccinated visitors entering Singapore." However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

No coding changes to the period of 05-11 April 2022.    Further easing of COVID safety measures in-country will include resumptions of the nightlife sector from April 19. However, some safety measurements remain in-place, including vaccine-differentiated measurements.  __________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: All nightlife businesses, including nightclubs and discotheques, will be allowed to fully reopen from Apr 19.  This is in line with Singapore's recent easing of COVID-19 measures, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) and Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) in a joint media release on Monday (Apr 4). All nightlife establishments will be subjected to the safe management measures imposed on food and beverage outlets, retail liquor establishments and live performances where applicable, said the authorities.    For nightlife businesses where dancing among patrons is one of the intended activities - such as nightclubs and discotheques - patrons have to produce a negative antigen rapid test (ART) before entering the premises. The ART has to be supervised by a test provider approved by the Ministry of Health, either in-person or remotely. The COVID-19 test will be valid for 24 hours from the time of the test result.  "    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.04.11-033030/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-nightlife-businesses-fully-reopen-april-19-mti-mha-2606391  ________________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE: Groups of 10 vaccinated people will be allowed to dine in at food and beverage outlets from Mar 29, in line with Singapore's move to increase the size limit for social gatherings and household visitors. This also applies to hawker centres and coffee shops where full checks on vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) are implemented at their entrances, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Thursday (Mar 24)." Although there have been some adjustments to covid measures, there are still some specific restrictions depending on the type and capacity of the event.  ____________    Quote (1):    "Capacity Limits    From 4 March 2022, specific event size limits for events such as religious services, business events, media conferences, funerary memorial events, wedding receptions, and mask-on classes1, will be lifted. Zoning requirements will also be removed.    However, for large events and settings which pose more infection risks, capacity limits will be imposed as a precaution. These will include attractions, cruises, MICE and large work-related events, as well as large performing arts venues or sports stadiums. For other settings such as shopping malls and large standalone stores, the current density limit of 10sqm/pax roughly translates to 50% capacity too. For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

No coding changes for the period of 13-28 March 2022    Streamlining of Covid measures delayed until 29 March 2022. Vaccine-differentiated rules still apply.    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - There will be an easing off on mandatory mask-wearing outdoors from next Tuesday (March 29), as Singapore moves towards a new phase of living with Covid-19.  This was among a number of key changes to measures implemented in the fight against the pandemic that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and the multi-ministry task force tackling Covid-19 announced on Thursday.  They include larger group sizes and the lifting of most restrictions for fully-vaccinated visitors entering Singapore."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220328063941/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/outdoor-mask-wearing-not-mandatory-from-march-29-gatherings-allowed-for-up-to-10  -----------------------------------------  Quote (2):  "6.             The SMM 1-5 framework consists of five key parameters: (i) group sizes; (ii) mask-wearing; (iii) workplace requirements; (iv) safe distancing; and (v) capacity limits. As the local situation has improved considerably, we will ease the community SMMs along these five parameters.  From 29 March 2022, we will implement the following adjustments (see Annex A for more details):  c.     Workplace Requirements. Up to 75% of employees who are able to work from home can now return to the workplace, an increase from the current limit of 50%. We will continue to align the rules for social gatherings in workplaces and other social settings, so long as the general group size and masking rules are adhered to.    d.    Safe Distancing. Safe distancing continues to be encouraged but will not be required between individuals or groups for mask-on settings. A safe distance of 1 metre will continue to be required for mask-off settings. between individuals or between groups up to the prevailing group size limit. Notwithstanding this, we still need to guard against gatherings of big crowds, even if they have their masks on. Hence, we will continue to impose capacity limits, as described below.    e.    Capacity Limits. The capacity limit of 50% for large events and settings of more than 1,000 pax1 will be increased to 75%. This means that:  i.     For smaller settings/events with =1,000 pax, they can proceed without being subject to any capacity limit.  ii.     For larger settings/events with >1,000 pax and that are mask-on2, they will be subject to operating within 75% of the capacity limit of the venue. For mask-off events, individuals or groups of individuals up to the prevailing group size will be required to comply with the 1 metre safe distancing requirement.    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220328063645/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/easing-of-community-smms-and-border-measures  ------------------------------------------  Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20220328063640/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures  ------------------------------------------    ***Please refer to notes dated 12 March 2022:  no coding changes for the period of 08-12 March 2022. Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a.
